questions.question: 1. The loading curve during instrumented indentation is given by P=α_1 h^1.5 for which type of indenter tip:

explanations.a: The exponent of 1.5 is for spherical indenter tip, whereas a value of 1 for cylindrical punch and value of 2 is used for conical indentation tips.
explanations.b: The exponent of 1.5 is for spherical indenter tip, whereas a value of 1 for cylindrical punch and value of 2 is used for conical indentation tips.
explanations.c: The exponent of 1.5 is for spherical indenter tip, whereas a value of 1 for cylindrical punch and value of 2 is used for conical indentation tips.
explanations.d: The exponent of 1.5 is for spherical indenter tip, whereas a value of 1 for cylindrical punch and value of 2 is used for conical indentation tips.

questions.question: 2. The unloading curve during instrumented indentation using a Berkovich indenter tip is given as (where P is applied load, h is instantaneous depth, hf is final contact depth after unloading, hc is the and hmax is maximum depth, and α2 is constant):

explanations.a: The exponent of 2 is used for Berkovich indentation tips, and the unloading is defined by difference between instantaneous depth and final depth after unloading
explanations.b: The exponent of 2 is used for Berkovich indentation tips, and the unloading is defined by difference between instantaneous depth and final depth after unloading
explanations.c: The exponent of 2 is used for Berkovich indentation tips, and the unloading is defined by difference between instantaneous depth and final depth after unloading
explanations.d: The exponent of 2 is used for Berkovich indentation tips, and the unloading is defined by difference between instantaneous depth and final depth after unloading

questions.question: 3. The relationship of contact area (A) with the contact depth (hcontact) for a Berkovich tip is:

explanations.a: The geometric relation of the contact area for a three sided Bekovich’s as well as 4-sided Vicker’s indenter is ~ 24.5 h<sup>2</sup>
explanations.b: The geometric relation of the contact area for a three sided Bekovich’s as well as 4-sided Vicker’s indenter is ~ 24.5 h<sup>2</sup>
explanations.c: The geometric relation of the contact area for a three sided Bekovich’s as well as 4-sided Vicker’s indenter is ~ 24.5 h<sup>2</sup>
explanations.d: The geometric relation of the contact area for a three sided Bekovich’s as well as 4-sided Vicker’s indenter is ~ 24.5 h<sup>2</sup>

questions.question: 4. The following portion of the load-displacement curve is used to extract the Young’s modulus of material during instrumented indentation:

explanations.a: The first 5-20% of unloading curve is utilized in calculating the Young’s modulus as the immediate response upon unloading is purely elastic, and later portion of curve may exhibit plastic recovery and viscoplastic response.
explanations.b: The first 5-20% of unloading curve is utilized in calculating the Young’s modulus as the immediate response upon unloading is purely elastic, and later portion of curve may exhibit plastic recovery and viscoplastic response.
explanations.c: The first 5-20% of unloading curve is utilized in calculating the Young’s modulus as the immediate response upon unloading is purely elastic, and later portion of curve may exhibit plastic recovery and viscoplastic response.
explanations.d: The first 5-20% of unloading curve is utilized in calculating the Young’s modulus as the immediate response upon unloading is purely elastic, and later portion of curve may exhibit plastic recovery and viscoplastic response.

questions.question: 5. Which of the following equations govern the evaluation of reduced Young’s modulus from instrumented indentation:

explanations.a: The geometrical fitting and the contact area term result the expression of reduced elastic modulus as:
explanations.b: The geometrical fitting and the contact area term result the expression of reduced elastic modulus as:
explanations.c: The geometrical fitting and the contact area term result the expression of reduced elastic modulus as:

questions.question: 6. Young’s modulus of the material can be obtained from reduced Young’s modulus (E*) via following equation:

explanations.a: The expression of reduced elastic modulus (E<sup>*</sup>) is related to stiffness of instrument and sample ‘in series’ with superposition of strain components.
explanations.b: The expression of reduced elastic modulus (E<sup>*</sup>) is related to stiffness of instrument and sample ‘in series’ with superposition of strain components.
explanations.c: The expression of reduced elastic modulus (E<sup>*</sup>) is related to stiffness of instrument and sample ‘in series’ with superposition of strain components.
explanations.d: The expression of reduced elastic modulus (E<sup>*</sup>) is related to stiffness of instrument and sample ‘in series’ with superposition of strain components.
